I wanted to get some feedback on the evolutionary process, and how much 
evaluation is 'enough'...

I have analyzed 421 pictures so far (out of 3110).  That equates to 
8,357,762,728 samples.  Yes, that's 8 billion.  I've hashed the samples so 
that each is represented as a 27 bit number, and I rotate and mirror and 
invert as necessary to get the smallest 27 bit number that is able to be 
represented by that sample.  This means that if two samples are almost the 
same, just rotated, they will have the same hash value.  Now, after only 
saving one sample per hash value, I find that I only have 8,442,727 samples. 
  As each picture is evaluated, more samples are added, but at a fairly slow 
rate.  I expect the final count to come in under 10 million.  However, each 
of those samples can actually be represented 16 different ways, raising the 
count to closer to 160 million.

Now, let's say I had a thousand genomes in a population, and compared each 
to 160 million samples per epoch.  That's 160 billion evaluations.  I 
wouldn't live to see my project complete!

What I'm contemplating is a fitness evaluation heuristic to limit the amount 
of computation required.  The basic assumptions are these (correct me where 
I am wrong)

1.  Comparing the average fitness of two individuals does not require that 
each be evaluated on the same number of samples (by virtue of the fact that 
it is an average)
  -- Therefore, it should be possible to have an imbalanced number of 
evaluations per specimen per epoch.

2.  The narrower the standard deviation of the fitness evaluations, the 
higher the confidence there is in that average
  -- Therefore, we can stop evaluating the specimen once its statistical 
curve is well established

3.  Only some specimens will reproduce in a given generation
  -- Therefore, once a specimen has shown that it is relatively unfit for 
propagation, further evaluations are unnecessary against it
  -- And as soon as both non-reproducing and elite specimens are identified, 
further evaluation is unnecessary for that species

So the proposed algorithm would be something like this:

Evaluate each member of a species on a sample
Sort the results
Divide the list into those that will reproduce, and those that won't.  (If I 
can do that at this stage...can I?)
Repeat until the list of those that will not reproduce doesn't change for N 
evaluations
While doing this, skip re-evaluating any whose fitness evaluation we are 
confident of
If ALL those who will reproduce are also 'elites' then we are done...
Otherwise, continue to evaluate only those that are expected to reproduce 
until the elites are identified in the same manner as the non-reproducing 
specimens were identified.
The process for a species completes as soon as we know the genetic make up 
of those that will be propagating.

Now, since the number of offspring that a species can have is a function of 
the fitness of the average population, the above may be a little difficult, 
since we can't know ahead of time how many will reproduce and how many will 
not, right?  Well, wait, we have an intermediate average species fitness 
value, which could be used to make that division.  As the average fitness 
changes, the number of allotted offspring will change.  That will change the 
list of which can reproduce and which can not.  And since the algorithm 
defines the stopping point as when the list remains the same over a period 
of time, then as long as the average is stabalizing, it will continue to 
evaluate.  Though some individual ones might stop evaluating early if the 
confidence in their fitness evaluation is high.

That make sense?

Now what concerns me is that what I want from the end result is a network 
that has a high fitness evaluation for all 160  million samples.  So NOT 
evaluating against them all somewhat scares me.  But on the other hand, I 
know that I can't, so I need to rationalize myself out of that unhealthy 
desire... :)

If the samples are randomized (which to a degree, they will be), and I only 
have one sample per hash value (which will be the case), then I don't have 
to worry too much about statistical skew.  Over the course of many 
generations, the best specimens will have been evaluated against more and 
more samples, with ever increasing fitness.  The chances of the higher 
fitness against the later samples resulting in lower fitness for things that 
were previously evaluated against are fairly low (I hope).  So evaluating 
each generation against different samples than the generation before should 
be okay.

However, fairness would dictate that all samples in a generation be compared 
against the same samples, right?  At least until their low fitness 
disqualifies them for reproduction and thus further evaluation is 
unnecessary.  Or would it be okay, even potentially valuable, to perform 
every evaluation against a different sample?  (since there are so many of 
them available to work with)

Okay, so there are some thoughts.  Anybody have any feedback for me?

Thanks!

-- John
